keqe_expansions: Pineapples are tropical fruits known for their prickly skin and sweet, juicy flesh. Originating in South America, pineapples are now grown in various tropical regions worldwide. They are rich in vitamins, particularly vitamin C, and contain enzymes that may aid digestion. Pineapples can be enjoyed fresh, juiced, grilled, or added to both savory and sweet dishes for a burst of tropical flavor. Whether eaten on their own or as part of a recipe, pineapples are a versatile and delicious fruit that can brighten up any meal.

Pineapples are tropical fruits known for their spiky outer skin and sweet, juicy flesh. They are a good source of vitamins and minerals, including vitamin C and manganese. Pineapples can be enjoyed fresh, juiced, grilled, or used in a variety of dishes such as fruit salads, smoothies, and desserts. With their unique and refreshing flavor, pineapples are a popular choice for adding a tropical twist to any meal or snack.
top_passages: Antioxidant and antiproliferative activities of common fruits.	Consumption of fruits and vegetables has been associated with reduced risk of chronic diseases such as cardiovascular disease and cancer. Phytochemicals, especially phenolics, in fruits and vegetables are suggested to be the major bioactive compounds for the health benefits. However, the phenolic contents and their antioxidant activities in fruits and vegetables were underestimated in the literature, because bound phenolics were not included. This study was designed to investigate the profiles of total phenolics, including both soluble free and bound forms in common fruits, by applying solvent extraction, base digestion, and solid-phase extraction methods. Cranberry had the highest total phenolic content, followed by apple,

The effects of fruit juices and fruits on the absorption of iron from a rice meal.	The effects of the chemical composition of fruit juices and fruit on the absorption of iron from a rice (Oryza sativa) meal were measured in 234 parous Indian women, using the erythrocyte utilization of radioactive Fe method. The corrected geometric mean Fe absorptions with different juices varied between 0.040 and 0.129, with the variation correlating closely with the ascorbic acid contents of the juices (rs 0.838, P less than 0.01). Ascorbic acid was not the only organic acid responsible for the promoting effects of citrus fruit juices on Fe absorption. Fe absorption from laboratory 'orange juice' (100
